content.description: This route has lots of lichen but good edges just like the rest of the routes in the zone. There is not much of a ledge to start this route from, but there's a bolt at the ledge to protect the belay.
content.location:
Scramble to the base of

The Old Laughing Lady

, and then keep trending right. You can see the anchors for this route when you first enter the gully.

content.description: Sugar Mountain leans left at the start and then continues straight up.
content.location: Scramble up onto a ledge to find the start of the route.

content.description: The Old Laughing Lady is less aesthetic than other routes but has decent climbing. Trend left following a steep gully.
content.location:
It is the first route you'll see when enter the gully after hiking over from

The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

.

content.description:
Like a Hurricane climbs quality edges that will clean up with traffic. This has a solid runout from the last bolt to the anchor where the climbing eases to 5.8ish. You could protect this section with one #0.3/0.4/0.5 or easily traverse to the anchor for

Broken Arrow

just to the right if you are not into it. A 70 meter rope just reaches, but a 60m will require use of the gully and trees to the left.
content.location: This route is the furthest up the gully on the Decade Wall. Start on the left of a large, clean face with a massive dead log sitting in the air horizontally at the base of the route.

climbs.name: The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

content.description:
Located at the end of the approach trail are two bolted climbs. This is the right line, which begins on an arete.

P1 (70 feet): Follow bolts up the arete and eventually move left and climb through a roof on great jugs to a two-bolt anchor/stance. (5.7)

P2 (70 feet): Follow bolts (~8ish) up the face to the top of the pedestal. Anchors exist on the steep face for a heinous hanging belay, or bring a finger-sized piece and equalize to a bolt on the nice, comfy ledge for a better belay experience. (5.9)

P3 (70 feet): Move belay right 30 feet (through small, chossy notch). Climb the beautiful face following great incut edges to a two-bolt anchor (best to set this as a TR for your 2nd). (5.10-)

Rappel the route.

It is possible to link pitches 1 and 2 with a 60m rope.
content.protection: All bolts and anchors are in great condition, a finger-sized piece is optional for 2nd belay.
content.location:
The bolted route immediately to the left of the GBU is a

5.13ish roof project

that can be top-roped from the same first pitch anchor.

content.description:
Originally, this was submitted as a project.

Per

Thomas Martin 2

: start at the same point as the

GBU

, but go left up the easy slab flowing the bolt line and curving back right to the left side of the roof. Use underclings, pinches, and crimps to move through the blocky lower roof. In the lower roof section, clip the draw from a palm press on the left block with your feet on the right block. From the final crimp and pinch of the lower roof, reach out right to a blind, sloping, 3 finger gaston, and press up to a deep rail. Next do an iron cross out to a small 3 finger crimp pocket, then bump in to an undercling pinch from the rail. Then get a high foot scum on the lip of the roof, drop your knee in to a sloping rail, and bump your hand from the pinch to the good 3 finger pocket in the corner of the dihedral. Then bump your right hand up to a blind, deep, 4 finger pocket jug, and then climb right to the anchors.
content.protection:
7 bolts with a 2 bolt rap anchor.

Thomas Martin 2

recommends a longer quickdraw for the crux clip ("I used a 1 foot quickdraw").
content.location:
This is under the large, clean roof 15 feet left of the

The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

arete start.

content.description:
Broken Arrow climbs awesome edges and is bolted more closely than

Like a Hurricane

. The upper section still needs some lichen cleaning but climbs nicely.
content.location:
Start under the huge horizontal log 10 feet to the right of

Like a Hurricane

. It ascends the uppermost wall in the Decade Wall area.

content.description:
This route is located 20 feet left of the

The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly

routes and begins on a very dirty arete.

The route follows the arete for 3 bolts, then climbs left and follows a beautiful face for 12 bolts (or so).

This is probably one of the most intense moss and lichen experiences I have had in the Gunnison Valley. The upper face will be spectacular with some cleaning as it contains some really nice edges and fun movement, but for now, the route is enjoyable, but filthy.

Descent: rappel into the gully climber's left to a two bolt anchor (25m), then a second rappel to the ground through the dirty gully.
